title: Who was a better guitarist: Eric Clapton or Jimi Hendrix? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, let's see what Clapton said about it, according to those who were there and heard him. And what Clapton's Cream band-mates thought as well. It’s a story … When Hendrix had just come to England in fall, 1966 - brought over by the Animals' bassist and now-his-manager Chas Chandler -- and was playing in the after-hours clubs in London, word quickly got out about him. And the 'rock royalty' was soon coming to see him, including John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison Jeff Beck, Eric Clapton, Brian Jones, Mick Jagger, Pete Townshend, Roger Daltry. Paul McCartney told of one such visit on the Late Night Show this past fall ... Roger Daltry talks about another in the documentary: Seven Ages Of Rock - 1 : The Birth of Rock - Video Dailymotion Daltry was with Townshend and Clapton when they saw Hendrix, and Roger said, “Eric’s comment after Jimi played was, ‘I’m gonna f***er off and practice’.” The documentary then goes in to describe the time — also in this same period — when Hendrix actually jammed with Cream in a 1966 London gig. Jack Bruce, talking about it, said (in the same documentary), “He plugged into my bass amp … he did a version of Killing Floor (Howlin Wolf song - that supposedly, according to a reporter who was there, Clapton considered too hard to play) … blues all the way … he just played his ass off, basically. The first time I saw Eric I thought, ‘Ah, master guitar player’ … but Jimi was some force of nature.” Ginger Baker added: “Eric just stands there and plays … we got this guy (Hendrix) and he’s on his knees, and playing with his teeth …” Baker again: “It was like, WOW … I know it had a tremendous effect on Eric.” Chas Chandler said: “Eric’s hands are on the guitar … he just drops his hands, and he just stood there looking at Jimi … and he just walked off the stage … I ran back stage, and Eric was trying to light a cigarette … his hands were shaking … (mumbling) ‘Is he really that good?’” (And BTW, Jeff Beck, for his part, said this about seeing Hendrix: “It was like a bomb going off in the right place … I couldn’t do what he did .. I just went away from there thinking I better think of something else to do.”  So ... here's the thing to me. A comparison. Clapton was (is) a true blue guitar virtuoso. As Jack Bruce said it, a Master Guitarist. Lightning fast, clean, and with elite musicality. He's an A+ Hendrix: (i) he was sloppier, because he didn't care about that. He cared about extending limits, pushing into new sounds and effects. Launching into new galaxies of guitar playing. (ii) as Jack Bruce said, Hendrix was a 'force of nature' -- a natural showman supreme. Whereas Clapton was/is no showman at all, really. (iii) I also always remember - this all seemed to come easy to Jimi, he was so supremely talented. So focusing on playing 'clean' wouldn’ve been easy for him. (iv) Jimi was also a better, and more natural songwriter. Clapton often had co-writers for his songs IIRC, even if uncredited.  So ... who was better? To me it depends strictly on your 'cup of tea’. If you're a blues purist, you're gonna prefer Clapton, probably - nothing wrong with that. Me? I take Jimi.  (Jimi, final tour (which I saw, tho not this stop … he made the same comment wrt “Watchtower” when I saw him) … here’s “Voodoo Child” …)

Questions like this are rather odd to ask. It always seems like it is a question about someone’s technical/physical ability, but practically everyone answers it with regard to the music and not with regard to technical proficiency on the instrument. You can talk about someone’s technical/physical ability and proficiency objectively, but talking about music is a purely subjective matter. And talking about a purely subjective matter as though it were an objective and technical thing makes no sense. While there is a scholarly aspect to music, and you can dissect songs via musical theory, that’s not really what is ever being considered with a question like this. From a technical/physical ability standpoint, frankly, Clapton isn’t very good, and Hendrix isn’t much better. They’re adequate at “playing the guitar” but neither is what you would call a virtuoso on the instrument, despite what most people might say. They’re not incredibly technically proficient. I’ve been casually playing the guitar for over 30 years, and neither am I. But anyone that’s played the instrument for a considerable period of time knows what takes skill to play and what does not require very much skill, as they’ve got some experience to make comparisons. If *I* can play something, it likely doesn’t require much skill to play. I’m a pretty average guitar player. And from a technical standpoint, nothing either guitarist ever released is difficult to play. Writing it is an entirely separate matter, and delves into that subjective side of things again. What most people usually say when this type of question is asked is actually referring to their music itself, which is a completely different matter. Some of their music, either one, might be considered incredibly beautiful by many people. But others may view it with indifference or disgust. You see, it’s like asking someone “Which car is faster, the VW Beetle or the Bugatti Veyron?” and someone trying to argue that the Beetle is obviously a way better looking car. So what? That person may love the way the Beetle looks, but that wasn’t the question asked. Neither Clapton nor Hendrix were incredibly technically proficient on the guitar. Neither one had technical skills the average Joe couldn’t achieve if they played the guitar for a few years. Musically, however, they obviously had a whole lot to offer or they wouldn’t have achieved what they did. But that side of things is purely subjective. If you want to see some guitar players that are very proficient concerning the skills it takes to play the guitar I would suggest searching for stuff by Steve Vai, Joe Satriani, Yngwie Malmsteen, etc. Searching for “guitar shredders” will bring up a lot of names of guitar players who are absolutely amazing as far as technical skills go. Whether or not you will appreciate any of the music they play is a completely separate matter, as that’s subjective. But from an objective point of view, guitarists generally known as “good shredders” possess an insane amount of technical proficiency and physical ability, and are good “guitar players.” But for the millionth time, music is subjective. :)
